canonical_explanation.text: A cell is the basic unit of life. All living things are made up of cells. Robert Hooke first discovered cells in 1665 when he looked at a thin slice of cork under a microscope. Every cell has three main parts: the cell membrane (outer covering), cytoplasm (jelly-like substance inside), and nucleus (controls the cell). Plant cells have some extra parts: a cell wall (rigid outer cover), chloroplasts (contain chlorophyll for making food), and a large vacuole. Organisms made of a single cell are called unicellular (like amoeba and bacteria). Organisms made of many cells are called multicellular (like humans, mango trees, and elephants).
rules: Three main parts of a cell: cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus
Cell membrane: thin outer covering that protects the cell
Cytoplasm: jelly-like substance where cell activities occur
Nucleus: controls all activities of the cell
Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplasts, and large vacuole
Animal cells do not have cell wall or chloroplasts
Unicellular: organism made of one cell (amoeba, bacteria)
Multicellular: organism made of many cells (humans, trees)

questions.question_text: What is the basic unit of life?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell is the basic unit of life. All living things, from tiny bacteria to large elephants, are made up of cells. Cells are the smallest structures that can carry out all the functions of life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Organs are made up of tissues, tissues are made up of cells, and atoms are not living. The cell is the smallest unit that is considered to be alive and is called the basic unit of life.

questions.question_text: All living things are made up of cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. All living things, whether plants, animals, bacteria, or fungi, are made up of one or more cells. Cells are the building blocks of all life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is actually true. Every living organism is made up of cells. Some organisms have only one cell (unicellular) while others have many cells (multicellular), but all living things contain cells.

questions.question_text: Cells are often called the _____ of life.
questions.explanation_correct: Cells are called the building blocks of life. Just as a building is made of many bricks, all living things are made of many cells. Cells are the smallest living units that combine to form tissues, organs, and organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While bricks, walls, and pillars are parts of a building, the correct term used in science is 'building blocks.' Cells are called the building blocks of life because all living things are built from cells.

questions.question_text: Anita looks at a drop of pond water under a microscope and sees tiny living things moving around. What are these tiny living things made up of?
questions.explanation_correct: The tiny living things Anita sees are made up of cells. All living things, even the smallest organisms found in pond water like amoeba and paramecium, are made of cells. These are unicellular organisms made of just one cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dust particles, water molecules, and sand grains are not living things. The tiny organisms moving in pond water are living things made of cells. Many of them are single-celled organisms like amoeba.

questions.question_text: Why can we not see most cells with our naked eyes?

options.text: Because cells are too small to be seen without a microscope
Because cells only exist inside the body

questions.explanation_correct: Most cells are extremely small and cannot be seen with our naked eyes. We need a microscope to see them because they are measured in micrometres, which is thousands of times smaller than a millimetre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cells are not invisible or only found inside the body. The reason we cannot see most cells is that they are too tiny. A microscope magnifies objects many times, making these tiny cells visible to us.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT true about cells?

options.text: Cells are the basic unit of life
All living things are made of cells
All cells can be seen with naked eyes

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'All cells can be seen with naked eyes' is NOT true. Most cells are too small to be seen without a microscope. Only a few cells like the ostrich egg are large enough to be seen by our eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cells are indeed the basic unit of life, all living things are made of cells, and cells do carry out life processes. The false statement is that all cells can be seen with naked eyes, because most cells require a microscope to be viewed.

questions.question_text: Which part of the cell controls all its activities?
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus controls all the activities of the cell. It is like the brain of the cell and contains the instructions for how the cell should grow, work, and reproduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane is the outer covering, the cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance inside, and the cell wall is an extra covering found only in plant cells. The nucleus is the control centre that directs all cell activities.

questions.question_text: The thin outer covering of a cell that protects it is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is the thin outer covering that protects the cell. It controls what goes in and out of the cell, acting like a gatekeeper. All cells, both plant and animal, have a cell membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell wall is a rigid outer covering found only in plant cells (outside the cell membrane). The nucleus controls the cell, and the cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance inside. The cell membrane is the thin protective covering present in all cells.

questions.question_text: The jelly-like substance inside the cell where all the cell parts float is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance that fills the cell. All the cell parts (organelles) float in the cytoplasm, and many important chemical reactions take place in it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is the control centre, chloroplasts are for making food in plant cells, and vacuoles store substances. Cytoplasm is the jelly-like material that fills the cell and holds all the other parts in place.

questions.question_text: The three main parts of a cell are cell membrane, _____, and nucleus.
questions.explanation_correct: The three main parts of a cell are the cell membrane (outer covering), cytoplasm (jelly-like substance inside), and nucleus (control centre). These three parts are found in all living cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell wall and chloroplasts are found only in plant cells, and vacuoles are storage spaces. The three main parts common to all cells are the cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus.

questions.question_text: Raj says the nucleus is like the brain of the cell. Why is this comparison correct?

options.text: Because the nucleus is the biggest part of the cell
Because the nucleus controls all activities of the cell, just as the brain controls the body
Because the nucleus is round like the brain

questions.explanation_correct: This comparison is correct because the nucleus controls all the activities of the cell, just as the brain controls all the activities of the body. The nucleus contains instructions that tell the cell what to do, how to grow, and when to divide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The comparison is not about size or shape. The nucleus cannot think like a brain. The comparison is valid because both the nucleus and the brain serve as control centres - the nucleus for the cell and the brain for the body.

questions.question_text: Which part of the cell acts as a gatekeeper, controlling what enters and leaves the cell?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane acts as a gatekeeper. It controls what substances can enter the cell and what can leave. It allows useful substances like food and oxygen to come in and waste materials to go out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus controls cell activities, the cytoplasm fills the cell, and the cell wall provides rigid support in plant cells. The cell membrane is the one that selectively allows substances to enter and leave the cell.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell wall is a rigid, thick outer covering found only in plant cells. It lies outside the cell membrane and gives the plant cell a fixed, rectangular shape. Animal cells do not have a cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell membrane, nucleus, and cytoplasm are found in both plant and animal cells. The cell wall is the structure unique to plant cells (and some other organisms like fungi and bacteria), giving them a rigid shape.

questions.question_text: Chloroplasts are found in plant cells. What is their function?

options.text: They help the plant make food using sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts contain a green pigment called chlorophyll, which helps plants make food using sunlight through the process of photosynthesis. This is why leaves are green - because of the chlorophyll in the chloroplasts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protection is done by the cell membrane and cell wall, control is done by the nucleus, and water is stored in vacuoles. Chloroplasts specifically help plants make food through photosynthesis using sunlight.

questions.question_text: Compared to animal cells, plant cells have a _____ vacuole.
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a larger vacuole compared to animal cells. The large central vacuole in plant cells stores water, nutrients, and waste products. It helps maintain the shape of the plant cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plant cells have larger vacuoles, not smaller or same size. Animal cells may have several small vacuoles, but plant cells typically have one large central vacuole that can take up most of the cell's space.

questions.question_text: Animal cells have chloroplasts just like plant cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Animal cells do not have chloroplasts. Only plant cells have chloroplasts, which contain chlorophyll and help plants make their own food through photosynthesis. Animals cannot make their own food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells, not in animal cells. This is one of the key differences between plant and animal cells. Since animals cannot make their own food, they do not need chloroplasts.

questions.question_text: Why do plant cells have a rigid shape while animal cells have an irregular shape?

options.text: Because plant cells have a nucleus
Because plant cells have a cell wall that gives them a fixed shape
Because plant cells have more cytoplasm

questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a rigid (rectangular) shape because of the cell wall, which is a thick, stiff outer covering. Animal cells lack a cell wall, so they are flexible and can have different shapes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both plant and animal cells have a nucleus and cytoplasm. The size difference is not the reason either. It is the cell wall that gives plant cells their rigid, fixed shape. Animal cells have only a flexible cell membrane, so they can be various shapes.

questions.question_text: Deepa observes two cells under a microscope. One is rectangular with a green colour, and the other is round and colourless. Which one is most likely the plant cell?

options.text: The rectangular cell with green colour

questions.explanation_correct: The rectangular cell with green colour is most likely the plant cell. Plant cells are rectangular because of the cell wall, and they appear green because of chlorophyll in the chloroplasts. The round, colourless cell is likely an animal cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plant cells are typically rectangular in shape (due to the cell wall) and appear green (due to chloroplasts containing chlorophyll). Animal cells are usually irregular or round in shape and do not have green colouring.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the differences between plant and animal cells?

options.text: Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplasts, and large vacuole; animal cells lack these
Animal cells have cell wall and chloroplasts; plant cells lack these
Plant cells have nucleus; animal cells do not
Animal cells have cell membrane; plant cells do not

questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a cell wall (rigid outer covering), chloroplasts (for photosynthesis), and a large central vacuole. Animal cells do not have these three structures. Both plant and animal cells have a cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is wrong because it is plant cells (not animal cells) that have cell wall and chloroplasts. Options C and D are wrong because both plant and animal cells have a nucleus and a cell membrane. Only option A correctly describes the differences.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Plant cells can make their own food.
Reason: Plant cells have chloroplasts that contain chlorophyll.
Choose the correct option.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true, and the reason explains the assertion. Plant cells can make food because they have chloroplasts containing chlorophyll, which captures sunlight energy to make food through photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (plants do make their own food) and the reason is also true (chloroplasts contain chlorophyll). The reason correctly explains the assertion because chlorophyll in chloroplasts is what enables plants to make food using sunlight.

questions.question_text: An organism made up of only one cell is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An organism made up of only one cell is called unicellular. 'Uni' means one, so unicellular means 'one cell.' Examples include amoeba, bacteria, and paramecium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multicellular means made of many cells. Non-cellular and bicellular are not standard scientific terms. Unicellular is the correct term for organisms with just one cell.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a unicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba is a unicellular organism, meaning it is made up of just one cell. Despite having only one cell, it can perform all life functions like eating, moving, breathing, and reproducing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango tree, elephant, and rose plant are all multicellular organisms made up of millions or billions of cells. Amoeba is the only unicellular organism in this list, consisting of just a single cell.

questions.question_text: Organisms made up of many cells are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Organisms made up of many cells are called multicellular. 'Multi' means many, so multicellular means 'many cells.' Humans, trees, dogs, and fish are all multicellular organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unicellular and single-celled mean the same thing - organisms with one cell. Non-living things are not organisms. Multicellular is the correct term for organisms made of many cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a multicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: A banyan tree is a multicellular organism made up of billions of cells. Different cells perform different functions like carrying water, making food, and providing support.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacteria, amoeba, and paramecium are all unicellular organisms made of a single cell. The banyan tree is the only multicellular organism in this list, made up of billions of specialised cells.

questions.question_text: A unicellular organism like amoeba cannot perform life functions because it has only one cell.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Even though amoeba has only one cell, that single cell can perform all necessary life functions like obtaining food, breathing, growing, moving, and reproducing. A single cell is sufficient for life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Unicellular organisms like amoeba can perform all life functions within their single cell. They eat, breathe, grow, move, and reproduce - all using just one cell.

questions.question_text: Sunita has a pet dog and she also grows bacteria in her science project. What is the main difference between the dog and the bacteria in terms of cells?

options.text: The dog has cells but bacteria do not
The dog is multicellular (many cells) while bacteria are unicellular (one cell)
Bacteria are bigger than dog cells
The dog does not have a nucleus but bacteria do

questions.explanation_correct: The main difference is that the dog is a multicellular organism (made of billions of cells) while bacteria are unicellular organisms (each bacterium is just one cell). Both are living things, but they differ greatly in the number of cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both the dog and bacteria have cells. The dog's cells are not necessarily bigger than bacteria in the way described. The key difference is the number of cells: the dog has billions of cells (multicellular) while each bacterium is just one single cell (unicellular).

questions.question_text: Which pair correctly groups unicellular and multicellular organisms?

options.text: Unicellular: amoeba, human; Multicellular: bacteria, neem tree
Unicellular: amoeba, bacteria; Multicellular: human, neem tree
Unicellular: human, neem tree; Multicellular: amoeba, bacteria
Unicellular: neem tree, bacteria; Multicellular: amoeba, human

questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba and bacteria are unicellular (single-celled) organisms. Humans and neem trees are multicellular organisms made up of billions of cells. This is the only correct grouping among the options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba and bacteria are single-celled (unicellular) organisms. Humans and neem trees are made of many cells (multicellular). Any grouping that puts humans or trees as unicellular, or amoeba and bacteria as multicellular, is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Who first discovered cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke first discovered cells in 1665. He observed a thin slice of cork under a microscope and saw small box-like structures. He named them 'cells' because they reminded him of small rooms (cells) in a monastery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isaac Newton studied gravity and motion, Albert Einstein worked on physics theories, and Louis Pasteur studied germs. Robert Hooke was the scientist who first observed and named cells in 1665.

questions.question_text: Robert Hooke observed cells by looking at a thin slice of _____ under a microscope.
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke looked at a thin slice of cork under his microscope and saw small compartments that he called 'cells'. Cork comes from the bark of a cork oak tree.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While onion peel and leaf cells are commonly observed in schools, it was a thin slice of cork that Robert Hooke examined when he first discovered and named cells in 1665.

questions.question_text: Which instrument is used to observe cells?
questions.explanation_correct: A microscope is used to observe cells. It magnifies very small objects many times so that we can see them clearly. Most cells are too small to be seen with our eyes alone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A telescope is used to see distant objects like stars, a stethoscope is used to hear heartbeats, and a thermometer measures temperature. A microscope is the instrument that magnifies tiny objects like cells.

questions.question_text: In science class, the teacher asks students to observe onion peel cells. Which instrument should they use?
questions.explanation_correct: Students should use a microscope to observe onion peel cells. Cells are very tiny and a microscope can magnify them many hundred times, making them clearly visible for study.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A magnifying glass does not provide enough magnification to see cells clearly. A telescope and binoculars are for seeing distant objects. A microscope is the correct instrument for observing tiny cells.

questions.question_text: Why did Robert Hooke call the tiny structures he saw 'cells'?

options.text: Because they were shaped like mobile phones (cell phones)
Because they looked like small rooms (cells) in a monastery
Because they were made of cellulose

questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke called them 'cells' because the tiny box-like structures he saw in the cork reminded him of the small rooms (called cells) where monks lived in a monastery. The word 'cell' comes from the Latin word 'cella' meaning small room.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mobile phones were not invented in 1665. The name 'cells' comes from the Latin word for small rooms. Robert Hooke thought the tiny compartments in cork looked like the small rooms (cells) in a monastery, so he named them cells.

questions.question_text: In which year were cells first discovered?
questions.explanation_correct: Cells were first discovered by Robert Hooke in 1665. He used a simple microscope to observe a thin slice of cork and saw tiny box-like compartments that he called cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct year is 1665, not 1565, 1765, or 1865. Robert Hooke made this important discovery in 1665 using a microscope to observe cork.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is correct about cells?

options.text: Only animals are made of cells
Only plants are made of cells
Both plants and animals are made of cells
Non-living things are also made of cells

questions.explanation_correct: Both plants and animals are made of cells. All living organisms, whether plant or animal, are made up of cells. Cells are the basic unit of all life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not just animals or just plants that have cells. All living things have cells. Non-living things like rocks and water are not made of cells. The correct answer is that both plants and animals are made of cells.

questions.question_text: If the nucleus of a cell is removed, what would happen?

options.text: The cell would not be able to function properly and would die

questions.explanation_correct: If the nucleus is removed, the cell would not be able to function properly and would eventually die. The nucleus controls all the activities of the cell, including growth and repair. Without it, the cell loses its ability to function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is the control centre of the cell. Without it, the cell cannot carry out its life processes properly and will die. It would not become bigger or turn green.

questions.question_text: Which of the following structures is found in BOTH plant and animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell membrane is found in both plant and animal cells. It is the thin outer covering that protects the cell and controls what enters and leaves. Cell wall, chloroplasts, and large central vacuole are found only in plant cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell wall, chloroplasts, and large central vacuole are structures found only in plant cells. The cell membrane is the structure that is common to both plant and animal cells.

questions.question_text: Plant cells appear green because they contain _____ in their chloroplasts.
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells appear green because they contain chlorophyll in their chloroplasts. Chlorophyll is a green pigment that captures sunlight energy for photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starch is food stored by plants, cytoplasm is a jelly-like substance, and water is colourless. Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in chloroplasts that gives plants their green colour.

questions.question_text: Kumar scrapes the inside of his cheek with a clean toothpick and observes it under a microscope. He sees flat, irregular-shaped cells. Are these plant cells or animal cells?

options.text: Plant cells, because they are flat
Animal cells, because they are from a human and have an irregular shape

questions.explanation_correct: These are animal cells because they come from a human (humans are animals). They have an irregular shape because animal cells do not have a rigid cell wall. Plant cells would appear rectangular due to their cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cells from the inside of a human cheek are animal cells. They appear irregular in shape because they lack a cell wall. Plant cells have a cell wall that gives them a fixed, rectangular shape.

questions.question_text:
Match the cell parts with their functions:
(i) Cell membrane - (a) Controls cell activities
(ii) Cytoplasm - (b) Protects and controls entry/exit
(iii) Nucleus - (c) Jelly-like substance for reactions
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct match is: Cell membrane - Protects and controls entry/exit (b), Cytoplasm - Jelly-like substance where reactions occur (c), Nucleus - Controls cell activities (a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: The cell membrane is the outer covering that controls what enters and leaves (b). The cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance inside the cell (c). The nucleus is the control centre that directs all activities (a).

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about unicellular organisms is correct?

options.text: They cannot move on their own
They can perform all life functions with just one cell
They can only be found in water

questions.explanation_correct: Unicellular organisms can perform all life functions - eating, breathing, growing, moving, and reproducing - with just one cell. That single cell does everything the organism needs to survive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unicellular organisms can move (like amoeba), are not always harmful (many are helpful), and can be found in soil, air, and other places besides water. The correct statement is that they can do everything needed for life with just one cell.

questions.question_text: A hen's egg is actually one large cell. What does this tell us about cells?

options.text: Cells can vary greatly in size

questions.explanation_correct: The fact that a hen's egg is a single large cell while most cells are microscopic tells us that cells can vary greatly in size. Some cells are too small to see, while others, like the ostrich egg, are very large.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all cells are large - most are microscopic. It is not only bird cells that can be large. The hen's egg is indeed a cell. The important lesson is that cells can come in a wide range of sizes.

questions.question_text: Both plant cells and animal cells have a cell membrane.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Both plant cells and animal cells have a cell membrane. In plant cells, the cell membrane is found just inside the cell wall. The cell membrane is a basic structure present in all living cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The cell membrane is present in both plant and animal cells. It is the cell wall that is unique to plant cells. The cell membrane is a fundamental part of every living cell.

questions.question_text: Why can animal cells not make their own food like plant cells?

options.text: Because animal cells are too small
Because animal cells do not have chloroplasts
Because animal cells do not have a nucleus
Because animal cells do not have cytoplasm

questions.explanation_correct: Animal cells cannot make their own food because they do not have chloroplasts. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll, which is needed to capture sunlight energy for making food through photosynthesis. Without chloroplasts, animals must eat other organisms for food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Animal cells do have a nucleus and cytoplasm, and cell size is not the reason. The key difference is the absence of chloroplasts in animal cells. Without chloroplasts and chlorophyll, animal cells cannot perform photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: An organism made up of many cells is called a _____ organism.
questions.explanation_correct: An organism made up of many cells is called a multicellular organism. 'Multi' means many. Examples include humans, elephants, mango trees, and roses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unicellular and single-celled refer to organisms with just one cell. Non-cellular is not a standard term. Multicellular (meaning many cells) is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Robert Hooke used a _____ to discover cells.
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke used a microscope to discover cells. He looked at a thin slice of cork through his microscope and observed tiny compartments that he named 'cells' in 1665.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A telescope sees far objects, a stethoscope listens to body sounds, and a periscope helps see over obstacles. Robert Hooke used a microscope, which magnifies very small objects, to discover cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a living thing and therefore NOT made of cells?
questions.explanation_correct: A stone is not a living thing and is not made of cells. Only living things are made of cells. Mushrooms (fungi), bacteria, and grass (plants) are all living things made up of cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mushrooms, bacteria, and grass are all living organisms made of cells. A stone is a non-living thing and is not made of cells. Cells are found only in living organisms.

questions.question_text: Pooja compared the cell membrane to a school gate. Why is this a good comparison?

options.text: Because both are made of iron
Because both control who or what can enter and exit

questions.explanation_correct: This is a good comparison because both the cell membrane and a school gate control what can enter and exit. Just as a school gate allows students and teachers to enter but keeps unwanted people out, the cell membrane allows useful substances in and keeps harmful ones out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell membrane is not always open (it selectively controls entry), it is not made of iron, and it is microscopic (not large). The comparison works because both the cell membrane and a school gate act as gatekeepers, controlling what passes through.

questions.question_text: Bacteria are multicellular organisms.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Bacteria are unicellular organisms, meaning each bacterium is made up of just one single cell. Despite being so small, each bacterium can carry out all life processes on its own.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Bacteria are unicellular (single-celled) organisms, not multicellular. Each bacterium consists of only one cell.

questions.question_text: A student draws a cell with a cell wall, large vacuole, and chloroplasts. This cell is most likely from a:
questions.explanation_correct: A cell with a cell wall, large vacuole, and chloroplasts is a plant cell. Among the options, only a tulsi plant is a plant. Dogs, cats, and fish are animals, and their cells do not have cell walls or chloroplasts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dogs, cats, and fish are animals, and animal cells do not have cell walls, chloroplasts, or large central vacuoles. These features are characteristic of plant cells, so the cell must be from the tulsi plant.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the relationship between cells, tissues, and organs?

options.text: Organs form tissues, which form cells
Tissues form cells, which form organs
Cells form tissues, which form organs
Cells and organs are the same thing

questions.explanation_correct: Cells are the smallest units that combine to form tissues. Tissues then combine to form organs. This is the correct order: cells  tissues  organs. For example, many muscle cells form muscle tissue, and muscle tissue forms the heart (an organ).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from smallest to largest is: cells  tissues  organs. Cells are the building blocks that group together to form tissues, and tissues group together to form organs. It does not work the other way around.
